awd_abstract_narration:
The PIPELINE Network project will significantly enhance physics education by developing and evaluating methods to incorporate workforce-relevant skills and activities in the student experience. The majority of physics graduates at all degree levels will become scientists and innovators working in the private sector, yet very little of the knowledge they gain while earning their degree specifically prepares them for these roles (for example, few physics programs emphasize real-world applications of scientific concepts, communication skills, or basic business concepts, all of which are important to successful private sector careers). Adding workforce-relevant learning to the discipline will attract a larger and more diverse student body to major in physics, and by extension improve the quality of the future STEM workforce. The PIPELINE project will bring together efforts of six institutions to create and document new approaches to teaching innovation and entrepreneurship in physics which can be shared with the broader community. The project will also advance our understanding of how these practices affect student and faculty attitudes towards innovation and entrepreneurship in physics.

The goals of the PIPELINE network are to build students' workforce confidence, improve physics faculty attitudes toward private sector careers, foster better integration of academic and industrial sectors, promote innovation in the physics discipline, and build a framework for wider adoption of physics innovation and entrepreneurship practices. The project will accomplish these by implementing physics innovation and entrepreneurship (PIE) approaches at member institutions during each year of the project, revising approaches between iterations, and finally documenting and disseminating curriculum. Most importantly, PIPELINE will develop surveys and interview protocols which will investigate the link between PIE experiences and student and faculty attitudes about innovation and entrepreneurship, and which can be used by other departments for gauging, monitoring, and improving institutional change around PIE. These research findings and tools will provide insights and utility that go beyond the immediate partner institutions, and live on beyond the duration of the project. PIPELINE will generate a core network of experienced PIE practitioners, a readily accessible body of tested PIE curricula deliberately varied in scope to fit unique needs and challenges of future adopters, and robust insight into the obstacles to PIE implementation and how future adopters might address them.

Project Outcomes Report

The six-university project "Collaborative Research: the PIPELINE Network" created examples of innovation and entrepreneurship education tailored to physics students. The network then disseminated resources for other institutions to use in their own implementation of such education. The broadest impacts of such work are better preparation of physics graduates for employment in industry, for identifying and contributing to societal needs through the inventive use of physics, and for overall professional effectiveness using knowledge and skills that augment the traditional physics curriculum.

The CU-Denver contributions to this work are described below in five categories.

Develop educator resources on technical competencies for physics-enabled innovation

An expanding series of modular laboratory-based learning materials has been composed in the form of "smart" notebooks that contain text, mathematics, graphics, and executable computer code. The modules address competencies such as materials selection and testing, structural design, mechanism design, heating and cooling, electronic measurements, signal amplification and display, acquiring data from sensors, and motor control. Special apparatus was designed that can be affordably replicated for use in teaching such modules: an example is shown in the accompanying image. Under the auspices of the American Association of Physics Teachers, a twelve-member national task force has been organized by the principal investigator (Tagg) to further identify desired technical competencies and to develop broad instructional guidelines for the physics teaching community.

Develop new courses for physics student innovation

A two-semester Applied Physics Lab sequence gives incoming physics majors a head start with technical skills useful for early participation in university physics research, for internships, and for jobs in industry. A remote-learning version of the courses allowed students to use common materials and/or low-cost electronics kits along with personal computers to address a wide range of topics. An on-campus in-lab version reduced the number of topics and used specially designed apparatus to pursue topics in greater depth. More advanced technical competencies with specialized instruments and apparatus have been incorporated into an Advanced Physics Lab course for physics students at the third year and beyond (including graduate students). Informal curriculum - including a workshop run at two large national conferences for physics majors and at local Society of Physics Student meetings - engages students in identifying human needs, brainstorming solutions, and creating mock-up representations of intended inventions. A website and online colloquium was prepared on "Physics for Humans": https://www.spsnational.org/programs/outreach/physicsforhumans

Expand and develop the Innovation Hyperlab, a working environment for supporting student innovation through access to a broad range of technical resources

Laboratory project space has been developed to provide guided access to basic and advanced machining (including 3-D printers and a computer-numerically-controlled mill and lathe), advanced test and measurement instruments, electronics construction tools and supplies, optical tables and system components, digital imaging, a broad range of sensors, actuators, and computer-aided data-acquisition technologies. This is augmented by a large store of technical supplies and surplus instruments; expansion space is currently sought to make the augmented resources readily available to students and potentially to community partners, including K-12 schools.

Launch a student organization called PSI* (Physics Student Innovators *and Alumni)

The goals of the PSI* organization are to bring physics students' inventiveness to fruition through material and creative support; to foster employer, investor, and community awareness of the potential for innovation by physics students in the service of human needs; and to engage physics alumni to use their experience to aid student innovators. A local PSI* student group was started at CU-Denver in 2016 and now a national website to guide other universities in creating their own PSI* groups is available through the Society of Physics Students: https://www.spsnational.org/programs/outreach/psistar

Demonstrate the effectiveness of physics student innovators and provide evidence that such student innovation can be synergistic with ongoing physics research.

A particular domain of research, applied nonlinear dynamics, has been used to show how students can be the agents for adapting research themes to potential innovations and needs-driven applications. Examples are the application of the dynamics of coupled electronic oscillators to robotics control and the development of microwave systems for materials purification. An ongoing relationship with two ventures recently launched by physics alumni - Vita Inclinata and American Nanotechnologies - informs continued development of training for current students in translating student-initiated projects into actual business entities.

The learning achieved through these five categories of work has several types of impact:

(1) Increased opportunity for students to use hard and soft skills of technical innovation during their continued learning, in research, and on the job.
(2) Technical skills to cite in resumes and the capacity to discuss these skills in job interviews.
(3) A heightened awareness of the application of physics to areas of human need and a capacity to form and communicate physics-enabled approaches to meeting such needs.  
(4) Student inventions that eventually translate into student-founded companies to develop and market technical innovations.
